creator: kiserwr
title: Simple and Cheap Homemade Air Filter
description: This project provides instructions on how to build a simple and cheap homemade air filter to improve indoor air quality by forcing air through activated carbon to remove organic particles and pollutants.
steps: Wash the activated carbon using a strainer or screen to remove any fine dust.
Lay the washed carbon out to dry on a flat surface.
Measure the circumference of your fan using a string or measuring tape.
Cut a rectangular piece of cardboard with a length equal to the fan's circumference plus 0.25 inches for overlap, and a width equal to three times the fan's depth.
Roll the cardboard along the grain until it becomes malleable and form a cylinder.
Wrap the rolled cardboard around the fan and staple the overlapping edges to form a cylinder. Remove from fan and staple the other end.
Cut a hole in the side of the tube for the fan's power cord, seal around the wire with duct tape.
Attach the cylinder to the fan with duct tape, ensuring a tight seal.
Measure the inner diameter of the cardboard tube attached to the fan and calculate the inner circumference
Cut another piece of cardboard with a length equal to the circumference of the inside of the tube plus 0.25 inches and a width of 1 inch, then wrap it in duct tape to increase its sturdiness
Form the cardboard into a small cylinder (disc) and staple the top and bottom corners together.
Staple the screen material around one side of the disc, stretching it taut like a drum.
Turn the filter over and staple the screen to the other side, leaving a gap for pouring in the carbon.
Ensure the carbon is dry and pour it into the filter, packing it to the brim.
Close up the remaining part of the screen and trim off any excess material.
Ensure the switch on the fan is set to the on position and insert the filter into the cardboard tube and tape around the edges to ensure the perfect seal.
